body:
### Problem

I regularly build neovim from Git (through the `neovim-git` package on Arch). Recently I've had a strange issue where it seems on startup that there's a rouge `rg` being issued.

I did a `git bisect` to find that the commit that introduces this problem for me is ab102f188e86bdbfce1d4de2ef633092a906e8fe (by @gpanders).

I can't reproduce this problem with `xterm`.

### Steps to reproduce

* Given a simple `test.txt` with only the word "ABCD" on the first line.
* I open `urxvt`
* I run `nvim --clean test.txt`
* I observe that the buffer contains "gBCD" and that it is changed (as shown in screenshot below)

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/998898/98debdfe-6ae4-407c-82a8-b6e7f062f68a)

### Expected behavior

Buffer is not changed on start.

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

0.10.0 ab102f188e86bdbfce1d4de2ef633092a906e8fe

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

No

### Operating system/version

Arch Linux

### Terminal name/version

urxvt v9.31

### $TERM environment variable

rxvt-256color

### Installation

build from repo

comment_data.body: `neovim-git` package is not "build from repo" as it uses external dependencies. Try `neovim-nightly-bin`.

Sorry for being unclear; I use `neovim-git` for daily use, which is where I first experiences this bug. But I also built directly from source to verify and reproduce the problem and to `git bisect` it.
Oh, I can reproduce this using Nvim built from source.

The TUI is forwarding this:
```
<M-]>11;rgb:ffff/ffff/ffff<Escape>
```
The OSC response is missing a backslash?

This will fix the problem if you build from source:
```diff
diff --git a/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua b/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua
index 09d6d43e7..e49ae3d49 100644
--- a/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua
+++ b/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua
@@ -280,7 +280,7 @@ do
       end,
     })
 
-    io.stdout:write('\027]11;?\027\\')
+    io.stdout:write('\027]11;?\a')
 
     timer:start(1000, 0, function()
       -- No response received. Delete the autocommand
```

But it will not fix the problem for `neovim-git` because it uses external dependencies.

> This will fix the problem if you build from source:
> 
> …
> 
> But it will not fix the problem for `neovim-git` because it uses external dependencies.

Cool, thanks. Would you propose this as a fix for the current issue?

I don't quite understand why this would not fix the problem for [`neovim-git`](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/neovim-git), though.

I included the patch in the PKGBUILD file; after trying to build again with `makepkg` and running `nvim --clean test.txt` I now see this:

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/998898/0a3aa91b-7758-4a33-832e-0851955cd508)

This might be as expected, based on your previous comment about neovim-git needing external dependencies?

@lervag That issue is the same as https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26038. It is caused by a bug in one of our dependencies (libtermkey). The vendored/bundled version of libtermkey has been updated, but not "official" release has been made yet, so using the version from the package manager will still have that issue.

> This will fix the problem if you build from source:
> 
> ```diff
> diff --git a/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua b/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua
> index 09d6d43e7..e49ae3d49 100644
> --- a/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua
> +++ b/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua
> @@ -280,7 +280,7 @@ do
>        end,
>      })
>  
> -    io.stdout:write('\027]11;?\027\\')
> +    io.stdout:write('\027]11;?\a')
>  
>      timer:start(1000, 0, function()
>        -- No response received. Delete the autocommand
> ```
> 
> But it will not fix the problem for `neovim-git` because it uses external dependencies.

So this sounds like a urxvt bug that it only accepts BEL and not ST as a terminator?

If we apply this patch then we will see a lot more instances of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26038 happen, because now _all_ terminals will respond with the BEL terminator and anyone (regardless of terminal emulator) not using the updated/bundled libtermkey will have that problem.

The old C implementation used `\a` as the terminator too, but the response was not parsed by libtermkey.

> @lervag That issue is the same as #26038. It is caused by a bug in one of our dependencies (libtermkey). The vendored/bundled version of libtermkey has been updated, but not "official" release has been made yet, so using the version from the package manager will still have that issue.

Ah, I see. And thanks for the explanation. It does bring a couple of questions though. First, do I understand correctly that, since I'm currently relying on the `neovim-git` version from Arch AUR, I will have to wait until an official release of libtermkey? Or is there some way of relying on a bundled and more up-to-date version of libtermkey?

> > This will fix the problem if you build from source:
> > ```diff
> > diff --git a/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua b/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua
> > index 09d6d43e7..e49ae3d49 100644
> > --- a/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua
> > +++ b/runtime/lua/vim/_defaults.lua
> > @@ -280,7 +280,7 @@ do
> >        end,
> >      })
> >  
> > -    io.stdout:write('\027]11;?\027\\')
> > +    io.stdout:write('\027]11;?\a')
> >  
> >      timer:start(1000, 0, function()
> >        -- No response received. Delete the autocommand
> > ```
> > 
> > But it will not fix the problem for `neovim-git` because it uses external dependencies.
> 
> So this sounds like a urxvt bug that it only accepts BEL and not ST as a terminator?

:shrug: I don't know these things :)

> My theory is that st is sending the OSC 11 response terminated with BEL (0x07) instead of ST (0x1b 0x5c) as it should be. We learned recently that libtermkey https://github.com/neovim/libtermkey/pull/4, so if my theory is correct what is likely happening is that st is sending us the OSC 11 response and it is not being interpreted correctly by termkey as an OSC sequence. Thus, it never gets sent in the TermResponse autocommand and is instead treated like regular terminal input, where it then appears in Nvim.

@gpanders If I understand correctly, you mean that your theory for `st` also holds for `urxvt`? If so, then I could attempt to verify this by following the steps you outlined.
No. `urxvt` has a different bug than `st`.

> > My theory is that st is sending the OSC 11 response terminated with BEL (0x07) instead of ST (0x1b 0x5c) as it should be. We learned recently that libtermkey [neovim/libtermkey#4](https://github.com/neovim/libtermkey/pull/4), so if my theory is correct what is likely happening is that st is sending us the OSC 11 response and it is not being interpreted correctly by termkey as an OSC sequence. Thus, it never gets sent in the TermResponse autocommand and is instead treated like regular terminal input, where it then appears in Nvim.
> 
> @gpanders If I understand correctly, you mean that your theory for `st` also holds for `urxvt`? If so, then I could attempt to verify this by following the steps you outlined.

No, urxvt seems to have a different problem altogether. I can't run urxvt locally to verify, so I'm only going off of what @zeertzjq suggested, but it _seems_ like urxvt doesn't recognize ST (`\e\\`) as a valid terminator, but it does accept BEL (`\a`).

You can very easily verify this yourself though. In urxvt enter `printf '\e]11;?\e\\'` in your shell and let me know what it spits back. Then do the same with but with `printf '\e]11;?\a'` (note the different terminator).
`urxvt`'s response is missing the final backslash when query ends with ST.

Not sure how helpful this is, but I'm getting a very similar issue when using tmux on a remote server via the ssh using kitty. It doesn't happen when using kitty locally, or when using tmux in kitty locally, or when just using the ssh without tmux. This is using the latest nightly build.

> You can very easily verify this yourself though. In urxvt enter `printf '\e]11;?\e\\'` in your shell and let me know what it spits back. Then do the same with but with `printf '\e]11;?\a'` (note the different terminator).

@gpanders Here's the output (in screenshots):

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/998898/4f5ec649-1d80-4b55-b44b-1a1504bdd22b)

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/998898/0d30871a-eb34-4c12-ba2c-b69aae7e365b)

@lervag Thanks. Your screenshot confirms what @zeertzjq also said, urxvt is not including the `\` character in its reply, so libtermkey is not interpreting the reply as an OSC sequence. Instead, the whole reply is treated as regular input. As in, Neovim thinks you are literally typing the keys `11;rgb`. The `rg` in that string is what’s responsible for that `g` character replacing the `A` in `ABCD`.

This is certainly a urxvt bug. Our choices are:

1. Do nothing and wait for urxvt to fix their bug
2. Change the terminator in our query to BEL, which will cause problems everywhere that isn’t using our patched version of libtermkey, until a new version is released and distros upgrade

> This is certainly a urxvt bug. Our choices are:
> 
> 1. Do nothing and wait for urxvt to fix their bug

Does this imply that I (and other neovim + urxvt users) would be prevented from using any neovim version that includes the commit ab102f188e86bdbfce1d4de2ef633092a906e8fe until the bug is fixed in urxvt? Or would I somehow find the issue to be resolved after updates to libtermkey?

> 2. Change the terminator in our query to BEL, which will cause problems everywhere that isn’t using our patched version of libtermkey, until a new version is released and distros upgrade

This does not sound like a good choice.

I'm curious, though; this issue first appeared after ab102f188. So, that refactoring did break things for several users, me included. I wonder if it may be worth considering to revert this change? Or, alternatively, add someway to avoid the autocommand altogether?
Don't forget that the main issue here is that urxvt does not implement OSC correctly (while many other terminals do), so I don't think reverting is really called for.

>So, that refactoring did break things for several users, me included. I wonder if it may be worth considering to revert this change? Or, alternatively, add someway to avoid the autocommand altogether?

Reverting is _an_ option, but not one that I am in favor of. Generally speaking, we (as in Neovim, the project) want to write our code in a way that is best for us (the maintainers) and our users. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/ab102f188e86bdbfce1d4de2ef633092a906e8fe is undoubtedly a win from a maintenance and "code cleanliness" perspective. It _has_ caused issues for users, but all of these issues are bugs caused by the broader ecosystem, which https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/ab102f188e86bdbfce1d4de2ef633092a906e8fe has helped to uncover. The change itself is correct from Neovim's perspective.

Reverting https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/ab102f188e86bdbfce1d4de2ef633092a906e8fe allows those bugs to creep back into their dark holes and linger longer. Eventually, they will pop up again and bother someone else. The right course of action is to fix the bugs.

> > This is certainly a urxvt bug. Our choices are:
> > 
> > 1. Do nothing and wait for urxvt to fix their bug
> 
> Does this imply that I (and other neovim + urxvt users) would be prevented from using any neovim version that includes the commit [ab102f1](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/ab102f188e86bdbfce1d4de2ef633092a906e8fe) until the bug is fixed in urxvt?

That's correct. This would of course be unpleasant for urxvt users, but I want to stress that **the unpleasantness comes from a urxvt bug, not a Neovim bug**.

> 
> > 2. Change the terminator in our query to BEL, which will cause problems everywhere that isn’t using our patched version of libtermkey, until a new version is released and distros upgrade
> 
> This does not sound like a good choice.

We will not release a new version of Neovim without some kind of plan to distribute these patches to libtermkey. Option 2 is most likely what we will end up doing.

> > So, that refactoring did break things for several users, me included. I wonder if it may be worth considering to revert this change? Or, alternatively, add someway to avoid the autocommand altogether?
> 
> Reverting is _an_ option, but not one that I am in favor of. Generally speaking, we (as in Neovim, the project) want to write our code in a way that is best for us (the maintainers) and our users. [ab102f1](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/ab102f188e86bdbfce1d4de2ef633092a906e8fe) is undoubtedly a win from a maintenance and "code cleanliness" perspective. It _has_ caused issues for users, but all of these issues are bugs caused by the broader ecosystem, which [ab102f1](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/ab102f188e86bdbfce1d4de2ef633092a906e8fe) has helped to uncover. The change itself is correct from Neovim's perspective.
> 
> Reverting [ab102f1](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/ab102f188e86bdbfce1d4de2ef633092a906e8fe) allows those bugs to creep back into their dark holes and linger longer. Eventually, they will pop up again and bother someone else. The right course of action is to fix the bugs.

Thanks; very well put. I fully agree with this.

Now, I would be more than happy to help get things fixed at urxvt upstream. However, it is hard for me to properly explain this bug because I don't quite understand it myself.

> > > 2. Change the terminator in our query to BEL, which will cause problems everywhere that isn’t using our patched version of libtermkey, until a new version is released and distros upgrade
> > 
> > 
> > This does not sound like a good choice.
> 
> We will not release a new version of Neovim without some kind of plan to distribute these patches to libtermkey. Option 2 is most likely what we will end up doing.

Sorry if I'm being slow, but does going for option 2 mean that I might not need to wait for a fix to urxvt itself? That is, will patches to libtermkey imply that we avoid the bug in urxvt?

----

I do get the feeling that it will be quite a lot of time until we're at a situation where bleeding edge neovim will work properly. Thus, I would be very glad to find a workaround in the meantime. I tried commenting out the `do ... end` block in `$VIMRUNTIME/lua/vim/_defaults.lua`, which I would expect to fix the problem. But surprisingly (to me), it does not.

Good news, this bug has already been fixed in urxvt! https://github.com/exg/rxvt-unicode/commit/417b540d6dba67d440e3617bc2cf6d7cea1ed968 I guess it just hasn't made it into a release yet.

>Sorry if I'm being slow, but does going for option 2 mean that I might not need to wait for a fix to urxvt itself? That is, will patches to libtermkey imply that we avoid the bug in urxvt?

Yes that's correct. Although knowing now that urxvt is already fixed, I don't think we'll go this route anymore.
There's nothing actionable here for Neovim, so I'm going to close. For future readers with the same problem, keep an eye out for a new urxvt release.
Thanks, I much appreciate your help and information here; and of course, thanks for all your (all of yous) work on neovim! <3
I've reached out to the maintainer of rxvt-unicode and asked if it may be possible for him to make another release that includes the fix.
With #25870 merged this may be reconsidered.
No. Urxvt is still doing it wrong (well, not anymore when the fix is released).
That doesn't mean changing back to BEL is not an option.
I don't think we should add workarounds in neotermkey for bugs in terminal emulatators which has been _fixed_. Is this known to be a bug anywhere else? otherwise recommend closed-as-fixed.
It's not a workaround and not in libtermkey. It's restoring old behavior.
You mean changing behavior to only use BEL is "restoring old behavior"? This is certainly some doublespeak I am not familiar with.
Yes. In Nvim v0.9 BEL is used.

Yes, in the C implementation of requesting the background color we used BEL. Using BEL in the Lua implementation is fine. The argument against it earlier was the libtermkey bug, but now that that is vendored there isn't a reason not to do it.
yes, fixes in Nvim to behave correctly may expose bugs in other software. if urxvt would have _disagreed_ there was a bug on their end there might be a story here. but this sounds like a non-story.
There is nothing incorrect with the old v0.9 behavior.

ok, so libtermkey introduced a regression which we then fixed all during the 0.10 cycle. 

So it is more of a "it doesn't matter either way" scenario from our end, and BEL empirically triggers less bugs than the other option in external software.
Actually, the regression happened because of forwarding OSC response to libtermkey instead of handling it directly. The bug has previously always existed in libtermkey, but not triggered by Nvim.

labels.description: Needs a third-party / external change or fix
labels.name: status:blocked-external

labels.description: issues or PRs involving changing the defaults
labels.name: defaults

title: Strange bug with neovim and urxvt: Seems like something is running "rg" on startup
